author: Sarah Thomas
title: Sculpture by the Sea 2015: Jorg Plickat's climate change lament nets prize
text:

Sculpture by the Sea 2015 Hear what the artists have to say about their awe inspiring works at this year's Sculpture by the Sea.
PT2M39S http://www.canberratimes.com.au/action/externalEmbeddedPlayer?id=d-44yak 620 349 October 22, 2015 - 11:19AM Autoplay On Off Video feedback Video settings Sculpture by the Sea scholarship winners Inactivity on climate change is the pointed theme of this year's winner of the Macquarie Group Sculpture Prize at Sculpture by the Sea.
German artist Jorg Plickat's twisted corten steel work,  Divided Planet ,   has won the $60,000 prize from the 107 sculptures installed along the coast from Bondi to Tamarama.
Jorg Plickat's Divided Planet, which has won the Macquarie Group Sculpture Prize. 
The work, priced at $85,000, is a lament over the political blocks that impede urgent issues such as global warming and poverty.
Advertisement It's Plickat's third appearance at Sculpture by the Sea. His work has featured in 350 exhibitions worldwide.
Sculpture by the Sea founding director David Handley said: "Each time Jorg has exhibited at Sculpture by the Sea, Bondi, his works have stood out. It is wonderful to see a German artist receive the major award for the first time."
Divided Planet is on show at Marks Park but will be moved after Sculpture by the Sea to Headland Park, Georges Heights, Mosman, to stand alongside previous winners Ring by Peter Lundberg (2014) and Fallout by Stephen King (2013).
Plickat, who has been a sculptor since 1980, has had more than 85 public works installed worldwide.
Sculpture by the Sea runs until November 8.
